metadata.paragraph_text_preview: Involuntarily unhoused residents of the City of San Rafael, California, filed this lawsuit pro se on...

target:
Involuntarily unhoused residents of the City of San Rafael, California, filed this lawsuit pro se on August 11, 2023, in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California, requested a temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction to stop the City of San Rafael from enforcing ordinances that the plaintiffs alleged criminalized homelessness by making “camping” on public property a criminal offense. The plaintiffs were ten unhoused individuals and Camp Integrity, an unincorporated association of people and property where the unhoused individual plaintiffs lived. They sued the City of San Rafael and its Chief of Police under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 and the Americans with Disabilities Act. Plaintiffs alleged that the City’s ordinance violated their rights under the First, Eighth, Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution and the Americans with Disabilities Act. The plaintiffs argued that the ordinances criminalized survival activities, including eating and possessing public belongings in public spaces, and unconstitutionally targeted unhoused individuals while permitting identical conduct by people who had housing. They further argued that the ordinances criminalized homelessness by banning sleeping on public property while the City of San Rafael failed to provide enough alternative shelter for the City’s homeless population. The case was assigned to Judge Edward M. Chen.

On August 15, 2023, Judge Trina Thompson held a hearing on the plaintiffs’ request for a temporary restraining order. The following day, she granted the motion for a temporary restraining order, enjoining the city from enforcing the ordinance until a hearing on the preliminary injunction could be held. The court determined that the plaintiffs sufficiently showed that they were likely to suffer irreparable injury if the ordinance went into effect, that the plaintiffs would endure serious hardships under the ordinance, that temporary relief would serve the public interest, and that there were “serious questions” on the merits of the case. On September 6, 2023, the court held a non-evidentiary hearing on the preliminary injunction and the defendant officials of the City of San Rafael were served. The court extended the temporary restraining order on September 7, 2023.

The court held a settlement conference with the parties on September 20, 2023. The plaintiffs filed a first amended complaint on September 26, 2023, adding as plaintiffs two additional individuals and the San Rafael Homeless Union. The court held a hearing for the motion on the preliminary injunction on October 2 and 3 and granted in part and denied in part the preliminary injunction on October 19. The court permitted the City to enforce the ordinance but required the City to: allow 400 square feet campsites housing up to four people that were 100 feet apart; provide assistance to campers who needed to move to a designated space; provide replacements to plaintiffs who did not have tents or bedding that could fit within the compliant space; designate the permissible campsites that complied with the ordinance as modified by the preliminary injunction on street level maps; establish a registration process so campers could find permitted campsites; and not evict or prosecute any plaintiff who submitted a request for a reasonable accommodation based on disability unless they were provided with due process. There was also a mens rea requirement for violating camping regulations. The preliminary injunction applied only to residents of the encampment who had standing under this lawsuit as named plaintiffs or as members of the San Rafael Homeless Union.

On October 26, 2023, one of the named plaintiffs filed an ex parte motion seeking a temporary restraining order to stop the defendants from disrupting his campsite and arresting him for using a pallet under his tent as a foundation. The City opposed the plaintiff’s motion. On November 1, 2023, the court held a status conference and a hearing on the temporary restraining order, which the court denied the following day.

The court held additional settlement conferences monthly from November 2023 until May 2024. On May 6, 2024, the City amended the ordinance in response to the Court’s preliminary injunction. The amended ordinance allowed campties of 200 square feet for one person and 400 square feet for four individuals, a 10-foot setback from other campsites, and a mens rea requirement for violating camping regulations. Subsequently, the City filed a motion to dismiss the case, or alternatively, to dissolve the preliminary injunction, on May 10, 2024.

The City then filed a motion for limited relief from the injunction on June 12, 2024 under F.R.C.P. 60(b), as it sought to relocate ten to eleven individuals camping along Francisco Boulevard West in light of alleged fire risks to their encampment. The same day, the court, considering that notice had already been given that campers had 48 hours to relocate, scheduled a hearing on the motion for June 13, 2024. The court held hearings on June 13 and June 14, 2024, and on June 14, Judge Edward M. Chen issued an order conditionally granting the City’s emergency motion for limited relief from the injunction. The court explained that it was an issue of fact whether any of the individuals whom the City sought to relocate from Francisco Boulevard West were covered by the preliminary injunction in this case, and after weighing the likelihood of irreparable injury, the balance of hardships, and the health and safety risks, the court concluded that moving the individuals from the encampment would be permissible.

The court held settlement conferences at the beginning and end of July 2024. On August 7, 2024, the court granted defendants’ motion to dismiss and dissolved the preliminary injunction. The court determined that the plaintiffs had not shown a reasonable expectation that the government would reenact its regulation, that the ordinance as amended on May 6, 2024 did not raise the same issues as the original ordinance, and that because the amended ordinance had given the relief sought, the case was now moot. Therefore, the court no longer had jurisdiction to maintain the preliminary injunction, which was rendered moot as well. As of December 2024, this case is closed.

The plaintiffs were ten unhoused individuals and Camp Integrity, an unincorporated association of people and property where the unhoused individual plaintiffs lived. They sued the City of San Rafael and its Chief of Police under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 and the Americans with Disabilities Act. Plaintiffs alleged that the City’s ordinance violated their rights under the First, Eighth, Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution and the Americans with Disabilities Act. The plaintiffs argued that the ordinances criminalized survival activities, including eating and possessing public belongings in public spaces, and unconstitutionally targeted unhoused individuals while permitting identical conduct by people who had housing. They further argued that the ordinances criminalized homelessness by banning sleeping on public property while the City of San Rafael failed to provide enough alternative shelter for the City’s homeless population. The case was assigned to Judge Edward M. Chen.

annotation.explanation: Plaintiffs: Individual, described as ten unhoused individuals and Camp Integrity (an unincorporated association); later, two additional individuals and the San Rafael Homeless Union were added
Plaintiff: Ten involuntarily unhoused individuals residing in the City of San Rafael (pro se filers; names not provided)
Plaintiff: Camp Integrity, an unincorporated association of people and property where the unhoused individual plaintiffs lived
Defendant: City of San Rafael
Defendant: Chief of Police of the City of San Rafael
Filed pro se on August 11, 2023, in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California.
Parties: Plaintiffs were ten unhoused individuals and Camp Integrity; Defendants were the City of San Rafael and its Chief of Police.
Legal bases: 42 U.S.C. § 1983 and ADA; alleged violations of the First, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendments and the ADA.
Relief sought: TRO and preliminary injunction to halt enforcement of ordinances criminalizing camping on public property.
Alleged facts: Ordinances criminalized survival activities and sleeping on public property without sufficient alternative shelter, and targeted unhoused people compared to housed individuals.
Background: Plaintiffs lived at an encampment known as Camp Integrity.
Judicial assignment/background: case assigned to Judge Edward M. Chen; initial TRO hearing held by Judge Trina Thompson.
Initial pro se complaint filed August 11, 2023, with a request for a temporary restraining order (TRO) and preliminary injunction (PI).

target:

The plaintiffs were ten unhoused individuals and Camp Integrity, an unincorporated association of people and property where the unhoused individual plaintiffs lived. They sued the City of San Rafael and its Chief of Police under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 and the Americans with Disabilities Act. Plaintiffs alleged that the City’s ordinance violated their rights under the First, Eighth, Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution and the Americans with Disabilities Act. The plaintiffs argued that the ordinances criminalized survival activities, including eating and possessing public belongings in public spaces, and unconstitutionally targeted unhoused individuals while permitting identical conduct by people who had housing. They further argued that the ordinances criminalized homelessness by banning sleeping on public property while the City of San Rafael failed to provide enough alternative shelter for the City’s homeless population. The case was assigned to Judge Edward M. Chen.

On August 15, 2023, Judge Trina Thompson held a hearing on the plaintiffs’ request for a temporary restraining order. On September 6, 2023, the court held a non-evidentiary hearing on the preliminary injunction and the defendant officials of the City of San Rafael were served. The court extended the temporary restraining order on September 7, 2023.

The court held a settlement conference with the parties on September 20, 2023. The plaintiffs filed a first amended complaint on September 26, 2023, adding as plaintiffs two additional individuals and the San Rafael Homeless Union. The court held a hearing for the motion on the preliminary injunction on October 2 and 3 and granted in part and denied in part the preliminary injunction on October 19. On October 26, 2023, one of the named plaintiffs filed an ex parte motion seeking a temporary restraining order to stop the defendants from disrupting his campsite and arresting him for using a pallet under his tent as a foundation. The amended ordinance allowed campties of 200 square feet for one person and 400 square feet for four individuals, a 10-foot setback from other campsites, and a mens rea requirement for violating camping regulations. Subsequently, the City filed a motion to dismiss the case, or alternatively, to dissolve the preliminary injunction, on May 10, 2024.

The City then filed a motion for limited relief from the injunction on June 12, 2024 under F.R.C.P. 60(b), as it sought to relocate ten to eleven individuals camping along Francisco Boulevard West in light of alleged fire risks to their encampment. The same day, the court, considering that notice had already been given that campers had 48 hours to relocate, scheduled a hearing on the motion for June 13, 2024. annotation.explanation: October 19, 2023 to August 7, 2024: Preliminary injunction (granted in part and denied in part) permitting the City to enforce the ordinance but requiring: 400 sq. ft. campsites for up to four people spaced 100 feet apart; assistance to campers to move to designated spaces; replacements for tents/bedding to fit within compliant space; designation of permissible campsites on street-level maps; a registration process; no eviction or prosecution of any plaintiff who submitted a reasonable accommodation request based on disability unless provided due process; and a mens rea requirement for violating camping regulations. Applied only to named plaintiffs and members of the San Rafael Homeless Union.
September 20, 2023: Settlement conference held with the parties.
Plaintiff: Two additional individual plaintiffs added on September 26, 2023 (names not provided)
Plaintiff: San Rafael Homeless Union
October 19: granted in part and denied in part the preliminary injunction.
Amended complaint added two more individuals and the San Rafael Homeless Union as plaintiffs.

Preliminary injunction (granted in part) allowed enforcement but imposed conditions: campsite size/spacing, relocation assistance, replacement tents/bedding, mapped designated sites, registration process, due process for ADA accommodations, and mens rea requirement; limited to named plaintiffs and SR Homeless Union members.

Preliminary injunction: Heard October 2–3, 2023; granted in part and denied in part on October 19, 2023, with conditions (camp sizes/spacings, assistance, replacements, mapping, registration, due process for disability accommodations, mens rea requirement); applied only to named plaintiffs and San Rafael Homeless Union members.
First Amended Complaint filed September 26, 2023 (adding two individuals and the San Rafael Homeless Union).
Require City to allow 400 sq. ft. campsites for up to four people, spaced 100 feet apart.
Require City to provide assistance to campers who need to move to a designated space.
Require City to provide replacements (tents/bedding) to plaintiffs lacking items that fit within compliant space.
Require City to designate permissible campsites on street-level maps.
Require City to establish a registration process so campers can find permitted campsites.
Prohibit City from evicting or prosecuting any plaintiff who requested a disability-based reasonable accommodation unless due process is provided.
Impose mens rea requirement for enforcing camping regulations under the injunction.

Preliminary injunction terms: City may enforce the ordinance only if it (1) allows 400 sq. ft. campsites for up to four people spaced 100 feet apart; (2) provides assistance to campers needing to move to a designated space; (3) provides replacement tents/bedding to plaintiffs whose gear cannot fit within compliant space; (4) designates permissible campsites on street-level maps; (5) establishes a registration process so campers can find permitted campsites; (6) refrains from evicting or prosecuting any plaintiff who requests a disability accommodation unless due process is provided; and (7) enforces camping regulations with a mens rea requirement. Scope limited to named plaintiffs and San Rafael Homeless Union members.
Settlement conference: Held Sep 20, 2023.

Preliminary injunction merits hearing and ruling: Hearings on Oct 2–3, 2023; order on Oct 19, 2023 granting in part/denying in part. City allowed to enforce ordinance but with conditions (400 sq. ft. campsites for up to four, 100-foot spacing, assistance with relocation, replacements for tents/bedding, mapping/designation of compliant sites, registration process, due process for disability accommodation requests), and a mens rea requirement. Injunction limited to named plaintiffs and San Rafael Homeless Union members.

Oct 19, 2023: Court granted in part and denied in part the preliminary injunction—allowed City to enforce the ordinance but imposed conditions (e.g., 400 sq. ft. sites for up to 4 people spaced 100 ft apart, assistance to relocate, replacement tents/bedding to comply, mapping and registration of permissible sites, due process for those requesting ADA accommodations, and a mens rea requirement). Limited to named plaintiffs and San Rafael Homeless Union members.

target:
Involuntarily unhoused residents of the City of San Rafael, California, filed this lawsuit pro se on August 11, 2023, in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California, requested a temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction to stop the City of San Rafael from enforcing ordinances that the plaintiffs alleged criminalized homelessness by making “camping” on public property a criminal offense. The plaintiffs were ten unhoused individuals and Camp Integrity, an unincorporated association of people and property where the unhoused individual plaintiffs lived. They sued the City of San Rafael and its Chief of Police under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 and the Americans with Disabilities Act. Plaintiffs alleged that the City’s ordinance violated their rights under the First, Eighth, Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution and the Americans with Disabilities Act. The plaintiffs argued that the ordinances criminalized survival activities, including eating and possessing public belongings in public spaces, and unconstitutionally targeted unhoused individuals while permitting identical conduct by people who had housing. They further argued that the ordinances criminalized homelessness by banning sleeping on public property while the City of San Rafael failed to provide enough alternative shelter for the City’s homeless population. The case was assigned to Judge Edward M. Chen.

On August 15, 2023, Judge Trina Thompson held a hearing on the plaintiffs’ request for a temporary restraining order. The following day, she granted the motion for a temporary restraining order, enjoining the city from enforcing the ordinance until a hearing on the preliminary injunction could be held. The court determined that the plaintiffs sufficiently showed that they were likely to suffer irreparable injury if the ordinance went into effect, that the plaintiffs would endure serious hardships under the ordinance, that temporary relief would serve the public interest, and that there were “serious questions” on the merits of the case. On September 6, 2023, the court held a non-evidentiary hearing on the preliminary injunction and the defendant officials of the City of San Rafael were served. The court extended the temporary restraining order on September 7, 2023.

The court held a settlement conference with the parties on September 20, 2023. The plaintiffs filed a first amended complaint on September 26, 2023, adding as plaintiffs two additional individuals and the San Rafael Homeless Union. The court held a hearing for the motion on the preliminary injunction on October 2 and 3 and granted in part and denied in part the preliminary injunction on October 19. The court permitted the City to enforce the ordinance but required the City to: allow 400 square feet campsites housing up to four people that were 100 feet apart; provide assistance to campers who needed to move to a designated space; provide replacements to plaintiffs who did not have tents or bedding that could fit within the compliant space; designate the permissible campsites that complied with the ordinance as modified by the preliminary injunction on street level maps; establish a registration process so campers could find permitted campsites; and not evict or prosecute any plaintiff who submitted a request for a reasonable accommodation based on disability unless they were provided with due process. There was also a mens rea requirement for violating camping regulations. The preliminary injunction applied only to residents of the encampment who had standing under this lawsuit as named plaintiffs or as members of the San Rafael Homeless Union.

On October 26, 2023, one of the named plaintiffs filed an ex parte motion seeking a temporary restraining order to stop the defendants from disrupting his campsite and arresting him for using a pallet under his tent as a foundation. The City opposed the plaintiff’s motion. On November 1, 2023, the court held a status conference and a hearing on the temporary restraining order, which the court denied the following day.

The court held additional settlement conferences monthly from November 2023 until May 2024. On May 6, 2024, the City amended the ordinance in response to the Court’s preliminary injunction. The amended ordinance allowed campties of 200 square feet for one person and 400 square feet for four individuals, a 10-foot setback from other campsites, and a mens rea requirement for violating camping regulations. Subsequently, the City filed a motion to dismiss the case, or alternatively, to dissolve the preliminary injunction, on May 10, 2024.

The City then filed a motion for limited relief from the injunction on June 12, 2024 under F.R.C.P. 60(b), as it sought to relocate ten to eleven individuals camping along Francisco Boulevard West in light of alleged fire risks to their encampment. The same day, the court, considering that notice had already been given that campers had 48 hours to relocate, scheduled a hearing on the motion for June 13, 2024. The court held hearings on June 13 and June 14, 2024, and on June 14, Judge Edward M. Chen issued an order conditionally granting the City’s emergency motion for limited relief from the injunction. The court explained that it was an issue of fact whether any of the individuals whom the City sought to relocate from Francisco Boulevard West were covered by the preliminary injunction in this case, and after weighing the likelihood of irreparable injury, the balance of hardships, and the health and safety risks, the court concluded that moving the individuals from the encampment would be permissible.

The court held settlement conferences at the beginning and end of July 2024. On August 7, 2024, the court granted defendants’ motion to dismiss and dissolved the preliminary injunction. The court determined that the plaintiffs had not shown a reasonable expectation that the government would reenact its regulation, that the ordinance as amended on May 6, 2024 did not raise the same issues as the original ordinance, and that because the amended ordinance had given the relief sought, the case was now moot. Therefore, the court no longer had jurisdiction to maintain the preliminary injunction, which was rendered moot as well. As of December 2024, this case is closed.
target_paragraph: The court held additional settlement conferences monthly from November 2023 until May 2024. On May 6, 2024, the City amended the ordinance in response to the Court’s preliminary injunction. The amended ordinance allowed campties of 200 square feet for one person and 400 square feet for four individuals, a 10-foot setback from other campsites, and a mens rea requirement for violating camping regulations. Subsequently, the City filed a motion to dismiss the case, or alternatively, to dissolve the preliminary injunction, on May 10, 2024.

annotation.explanation: November 2023–May 2024: Additional settlement conferences held monthly.
Settlement conferences occurred monthly from November 2023 to May 2024.
On May 6, 2024, the City amended the ordinance to allow 200 sq ft for one person, 400 sq ft for four, a 10-foot setback, and a mens rea requirement.
City moved to dismiss or dissolve the preliminary injunction on May 10, 2024.
City’s motion to dismiss, or alternatively to dissolve the preliminary injunction, filed May 10, 2024.
Settlement conferences: Held monthly from Nov 2023 through May 2024.
Post-amendment dispositive motion: After the City’s May 6, 2024 amendment, the City filed a motion to dismiss or, alternatively, to dissolve the PI on May 10, 2024.

Aug 7, 2024: Court granted defendants’ motion to dismiss and dissolved the preliminary injunction on mootness grounds (amended ordinance provided relief; no reasonable expectation of reenactment), and thus lacked jurisdiction to maintain the PI.

annotation.explanation: June 14, 2024: issued an order conditionally granting the City’s emergency motion for limited relief from the injunction.

In June 2024, due to alleged fire risks at Francisco Boulevard West, the City sought and obtained conditional relief to relocate 10–11 individuals; the court deemed relocation permissible after weighing harms and safety.
Rule 60(b) motion for limited relief from the injunction filed June 12, 2024; conditionally granted June 14, 2024.
Granted limited relief permitting the City to relocate ten to eleven individuals camping along Francisco Boulevard West due to fire risks, notwithstanding the preliminary injunction.
Limited relief from injunction (June 14, 2024): City permitted to relocate 10–11 individuals camping along Francisco Boulevard West due to safety risks, notwithstanding the preliminary injunction.

Emergency motion for limited relief (FRCP 60(b)): Filed June 12, 2024; hearing scheduled for June 13 due to 48-hour relocation notice; hearings held June 13–14; order conditionally granting relief issued June 14, 2024 (Judge Edward M. Chen), allowing relocation after weighing irreparable injury, hardships, and safety risks.

June 14, 2024: Judge Edward M. Chen conditionally granted the City’s emergency Rule 60(b) motion for limited relief from the preliminary injunction to relocate 10–11 individuals on Francisco Boulevard West due to fire risks, after weighing irreparable injury, hardships, and health/safety risks.
